import React from 'react' import Nav from '../../components/Nav/nav.js' class What extends React.Component { render() { return (

What you can do

March 2020

Many thanks to Janina Dehghani, Jens Ihle, Nicolas Ritouet, Prof. Monika Schuhmacher for reading, commenting and re-writing parts of this.

"The world has gone mad". I've never thought deeply about the phrase before. The question whether the world has gone mad never came up to me. For me the world has never not been crazy. The craziness seemed to change only in waves: sometimes more, sometimes less.

Now I have children. It made me look for an answer. And the answer is that the world is actually getting crazier.

Let me share what I found out. To find an answer, all events in the world would have to be compared. If today's events are crazy and those of the past are less crazy, the phrase would have some truth to it. The good news is that a comprehensive investigation is not necessary. There is a little trick you can use in judging events to expose them as crazy. If the event is particularly unprecedented, we perceive it as crazy.

As everyone knows unprecedented events pop up everywhere. The two forces globalization and innovation fuel the creation of these events. Globalization causes an events reproduction and reach (n + 1) and the level of novelty causes the steepness of the curve (0 => 1). At its highest possible intersection the pull of humans toward the event is highest. Thus events tend to be unprecedented by nature and some event reach peeks.

It is not so long ago that the world is so densely connected. By now the world has learned to cope with globalization. But it has not tried a serious approach to address global issues with global institutions that make sense. The world can be compared to a teenager in an identity crisis. Physical possibility and still irrational judgement reaches its highest point of intersection. The results are unprecedented events hitting a teenager’s mind.

This becomes obvious with events that have impact on the context we live in. This varies by degree. Few people can remember the day when the first direct observation of gravitational waves was announced (February 11, 2016). For physicists this was a crazy event. But everybody knows what happened on September 11, 2001, even physicists. I am not saying that both events can be compared based on their content but how they impact society.

The level of impact is relative, since it changes during time. The amount of energy an event holds is interchangeable with its mass. Similar like atoms, even tiny events can hold massive amounts of energy.

In the course of time some events seem to be insignificant for a short time. Years later they turn out to be world-changing events. At first the birth of Christ was only important to a few people, let alone seen as a historical event. Today the calendar of the whole world revolves around His birth year.

Okay, so events in the world show that they tend to be unprecedented and thus are perceived as crazy. Does it make a difference knowing that?

It makes a big difference to me. It means that the phrase "the world has gone mad" is not only a figure of speech to express one's displeasure. It's not just a phrase to express disbelief. It makes me think about how to avoid and help change crazy developments. And the world for my children should not only not be crazy. It should be like Jürgen Klopp "the normal one." (2) Specifically, I ask myself what I can do to make my children happy and keep them happy.

To create happiness for my children, I need to know what makes up happiness (3). This is not as simple as it seems. Most people know when they are happy, but very few, including me, can define happiness (4). Less difficult is to look at the prerequisites for happiness on a macro level.

  • (1) Es ist klar, dass die Jugend die Welt bewegen kann. Jugendliche haben in der Regel ein viel besseres Gefühl für was möglich ist, als Erwachsene. Ich beziehe mich hier auf das Einschätzungsvermögen von wissenschaftlicher Seite aus. Jugend und Erwachsene müssen gemeinsam an der Gestaltung der Welt arbeiten.
  • (2) Sprunghafte Anstiege gab es in den Zeiträumen um: 3.000 BC, 6 BC, 1100 AD, 1200 AD, 1480 AD, 1780 AD, 1847 AD, 1900 AD.
  • (3) In der ersten Pressekonferenz für den Verein Liverpool in England beschreibt Jürgen Klopp sich als "the normal one&rdquohttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pb0tvv1ojU
  • (4) Maria Montessori: "Kinder sind anders&rdquo, Klett-Cotta Verlag, 21. Aufl. 2019.
  • (5) Arthur Koestler: "The Act of Creation&rdquo, Last Century Media, 1964, S. 85.
) } } export default What
